awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Passive Cooling Materials for Transparent Applications in Refrigerated Trucking and Solar
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to overcome the barrier to transparent passive radiative cooling materials that are applicable to commercial environments.  The project develops a transparent passive cooling thin-film applicable to situations that lose efficiency when heated, and where both mechanical and thermal stress are involved, for example, over advertisements on refrigerated trucks, or on the front face of solar panels. It will provide the simultaneous qualities of transparency in visible wavelengths, durability to withstand the elements, flexibility for ease of application, high cooling power to address customers' pain points, and manufacturability in a roll to roll format to minimize costs. The technology has the potential to provide a 25-80% increase in fuel efficiency via application of the thin-film to the outside of refrigerated truck trailers. The benefits to customers include: fuel cost savings, reduced emissions, allowing regulatory requirements to be met, decreased maintenance and replacement costs compared to refrigeration units and in-truck insulation in truck, as well as temperature maintenance in maximum heat.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project seeks to develop a thin-film product that could revolutionize cooling technologies across a number of industries. The demand for temperature-sensitive goods is expected to continue to grow significantly. To address the need for refrigeration with reduced fuel costs and emissions, the project is developing selective photonic emitters in thermal wavelength windows such that instead of heat being effectively enclosed in an insulating thermos (the atmosphere), they are exposed to a vast cold sink of space. The result is a revolutionary method of entirely passive heat management. This approach will be optimized in a thin-film photonics material that provides significant cooling to refrigerated truck trailers, saving refrigeration fuel costs. Phase I research objectives will establish proof of feasibility and include producing and testing promising material combinations at wafer-scale, testing to ensure that the material's qualities transfer to a commercially relevant size, and performing a small-scale test with potential customers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project focused on the development of a thin-film product that has the potential to revolutionize cooling technologies across several industries, including refrigerated trucking, solar, energy storage, automobile coatings, glass coatings for windows, and more. We developed selective photonic emitters that exploit thermal wavelength windows in the atmospheric transmission spectrum. The thin-film technology selectively emits thermal photons in wavelengths that pass through the Earth?s atmosphere unimpeded (8-13um). The result is a method of entirely passive heat management. The technology takes advantage of the second law of thermodynamics to allow certain wavelengths (heat) to be whisked above the atmosphere where they reach the vast cold sink of space at ~2? Kelvin rather than being trapped by the atmosphere. The thin film can be applied to external roofs of refrigerated truck trailers (among other applications in building materials and power generation and storage) and is durable enough to withstand extreme road conditions. Given that the passive cooling is inherent in the microstructure of each piece and there is no need for electrical continuity like with solar panels or other electrical devices, our product will provide seamless cooling capabilities, even in the unlikely event of the film being, cut, torn or pierced. Our goal is to develop cheap and scalable passive radiative coolers based on durable and flexible thin-films, that are practical and easy to install across many real-world environments, including applications where visible transparency is necessary. Within this context, our major research objective thus far has been the identification of the most promising materials that (i) have large cooling capacity, (ii) are transparent for wavelengths in the solar spectrum, (iii) are financially viable at scale and (iv) are durable. During this Phase I project, we identified the best candidate materials using a combination of real-world testing, laboratory measurements and simulations including: developing computer simulations to predict the steady state temperature and cooling power of a material, investigating how to predict the effective emissivity of a material using numerical simulations, formulating a number of composite films to test empirically, building two new outdoor testing environments for testing the cooling capacity of our films in various environments, conducting UltraViolet/Visible (UV/Vis), Fourier Transform InfraRed (FTIR) spectroscopic measurements on a variety of materials samples, and carrying out preliminary thermal imaging of potential application sites such as refrigerated trailers, roofs, solar panels, and battery energy storage systems to prepare for pilot testing with these applications.  Results showed 33-72% reduction in power demand for cooling, and more than 75 W/m2 cooling power, well in excess of the 1.5-2% efficiency increases from new technologies regularly implemented in the refrigerated trucking industry.

Broader Impacts:

Advancing the health and welfare of the American public. As our cooling films have the potential to increase fuel efficiency and reduce emissions related to refrigerated trucking, widespread adoption of this technology may curb associated greenhouse gas emissions, giving way to more sustainable cold chain operations. In addition, application to solar inverters or PV cells would increase the efficiency of renewable power generation. These uses collectively serve to improve the sustainability of multiple industries, with a long-term impact of offsetting the use of fossil fuels and the negative environmental, societal, and health effects tied to them. The ability to reduce emissions in refrigerated trucking can lead to improved air quality and our thin-films can reduce trucks? impact on global warming by decreasing greenhouse gas emissions by more than 15 MMT of CO2 equivalent per year in the U.S. alone. The improved efficiency of solar PV through passive cooling will also facilitate transition to these more sustainable forms of energy generation, building energy resiliency and sustainability.

Increasing the economic competitiveness of the United States. Delivery of Heat Inverse?s passive cooling thin films would bring a novel product to market that has the potential to substantially reduce cold chain costs. With its ease of application?whether for new or retrofitted products?and its compatibility for a multitude of industries, our novel cooling films are anticipated to have strong market demand. Given that there are no similar solutions currently available, development and global sale of our unique thin films as exclusively U.S.-manufactured products would uphold the economic competitiveness of the U.S. Further, U.S. adopters of our technology will benefit from reduced costs and increased operational efficiency, further giving them an edge over global competitors.
